moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3: In things like League or Ladder games, I vary my openings. But in tournament or mini-tournament games I usually stick to more Classical lines, as in this game.
moves.5... Nxd4 6. Nxd4: A pseudo-sacrifice, as the pin on the K file wins back the Knight at once.
moves.7... c6 8. Rxe4+: The capture with check allows time...
moves.8... Be7 9. Bd3: ...for the B to escape as well.
moves.9... d5 10. Re1: The fireworks are over for the moment, and I have a small material advantage. Time to develop that Q-side.
moves.11... Bd6 12. Bxd6: Since I'm ahead in material, I don't at all mind exchanges.
moves.12... Qxd6 13. Nd2: The last minor piece clears the rank...
moves.13... b6 14. Qf3: ...and development is finished, as my Rooks are connected.
moves.16... Rae8 17. Re2xe8: If Black now plays 17... RxR, I happily swap off the last Rooks with 18 RxR ch BxR and with 19 BxP I have a technically easy endgame win with my extra minor piece.
moves.18... Qh6 19. Bxf5: ...this move without moving into a self-pin. 19... QxQ 20 BxQ would let me win slowly but surely.
moves.19... Qxd2 20. Bxh7+: Now I win quickly. Black's only way to fight on is 20... K-R1 21 B-N6 dis ch Q-R3 22 QxQ ch PxQ 23 BxB, after which I have an easy endgame win but Black can drag out his resistance for a while.
moves.20... Kf7 21. Qe6#: Black's actual move enables me to end it right here.

opening: Ruy Lopez (C67), open Berlin defence, l'Hermet variation
